comments.author: tyvonable

comments.text:
+tyvonable You can learn to play music by ear, which is essentially hearing 
a piece of music and replicating it, but to be considered a professional 
musician you must know how to read music. If you went to college for 
Instrumental performance, you can be the best guitar player in the world, 
but you won't be accepted if you can't read music.
comments.author: Alex Rupert

comments.text:
+ssppeellll
Couldn't say it better myself.  Notation saves time and ensures the 
integrity of what the composer/song writer wants.
comments.author: Andrew Kroepel

comments.text: +ssppeellll true true.
comments.author: tyvonable

comments.text:
+tyvonable I don't read music, but I also play guitar and am a fair singer. 
But if I want to play a piece of music written 200 years ago, I'm out of 
luck unless I can find a recording of it AND have the ability to learn it 
by ear. And if it's complex, it will still be nearly impossible for me to 
learn it just by ear. 
I'm not saying we can't do great things without written music. I'm just 
saying there is great value in the written note, as there is in the written 
word.
By the way, just as reading and writing can be powerful tools for 
developing one's speaking ability (vocabulary, etc.), I'm pretty sure 
reading and writing music could also do a great deal to nourish one's 
composition and playing skills.
comments.author: ssppeellll

Isn't that a bit like saying being able to read and write is only useful if 
you want to be an actor?
Text--whether it is words or music--allows people to communicate across 
space and time. Literacy allows us to read the ideas of people we have 
never met--including people who lived long ago.

top_comment.text:
For those who say that Beethoven should not be compared to Bieber, you are 
right. It is not fair to Beethoven. Many people suggested it would not be 
good to BE Bieber. That he can't read music is not a radical claim, I doubt 
the Spice Girls can read words, but is unfounded. He CAN read music, and 
play the piano, and he wrote most of his own lyrics (and all the songs on 
his latest album).

I'm not a fan of his because I'm not a 12 year old girl. That's his fan 
base. They play with dolls and only speak in whispers and screams. Why are 
you listening to him, anyway? I don't care. But here's some facts about the 
person you would not want to be.
He has about 53 MILLION dollars in the bank and is a venture capitalist 
with a tech-heavy portfolio. His last concert movie made over $100 million 
dollars worldwide. He has the most-viewed video in the history of planet 
Earth with over 500 million views and when he tours makes about $600,000 
per show. He's 19 and Canadian. He makes more in a year than anyone reading 
this will make in a lifetime.

Now, let's compare an apple to an orange.

Ludwig was the oldest of 3 boys to survive birth, 4 died, and was a child 
prodigy in music. His mother died when he was only 18 and his father became 
a severe alcoholic. He became the breadwinner and went to court to get half 
his father's salary to feed his brothers and himself while taking intense 
lessons and performing. He always had money problems and was frequently 
quite poor and sick. He had chronic stomach problems, went completely deaf 
by age 26 and frequently contemplated suicide, which he wrote about in 
great detail. His brother became sick and died and Ludwig had his nephew 
taken from his mother by the court and sent to private school. The nephew 
attempted suicide shooting himself in the head, but surviving, then joining 
the army without reconciling.
He had horrible but incredibly romantic experiences with women. Denied 
marriage from his true love because he was a commoner and she was in a 
privileged family  he wrote the moonlight sonata, #14. For another lost 
love, he wrote Für Elise.  After a performance of his finally realized 
ninth symphony, he turned around to see a standing ovation thunderously 
applauding and he could not hear it at all, overwhelmed by sadness, he 
began crying uncontrollably.
He died at 56.﻿
top_comment.author: BariumCobaltNitrog3n

Music is what you make of it. It is man-made, and defined by humans. We

to play them. The video is a wonderful explanation on how to read modern 
music notation. I was just saying that there are many other elements to 
notations that are too important to not mention. Just my opinion. The idea 
or concept of music is to create human defined sounds onto the canvas that 
is the universe around us into the ears of others.

comments.text:
+Illusion Blade Haha thank you mate, but I was more talking about the way 
you guys use the name of notes. In France (and all European latin 
countries, I don't know about the others) we never use the ABC system, we 
only use do ré mi. It seems to me that the "do" in English is simply the 
root reference. But in French for example, we'll say that a trombone that 
plays in B flat simply is in B flat (or si bémol), not that the do is a b 
flat. I always assumed all European cultures used solfege the same way, the 
only difference might have been Do/C, but this thread has gotten me into a 
whole new world !

(by reading your post in French I'm wondering, do you speak French or was 
it google translate ? Cause it's pretty good !)
comments.author: Dave Sheik

comments.text:
+Dave Sheik Google translate!
Héy ! Permettez-moi de choses à nettoyer un bit .
Plus important encore, différents instruments ont différentes choses à 
faire . Par exemple : Trompette Do = C , Trombone Do = bémol , et ainsi de 
suite . Ce que vous parlez de ( Do Re Mi ... ) est nommé solfège . 
Considérez-les comme des lettres algébriques . Ils peuvent représenter ce 
que vous voulez , aussi longtemps que ce est pour votre instrument. Les 
lettres ( abc d ... ) sont les notes réelles , ou emplacements . Ils sont 
les notes de musique réels .
Donc en résumé , A, B , C , et ainsi de suite sont les emplacements réels , 
et Do , Ré, Mi , etc. représentent les lettres . Je espère que je pourrais 
aider !
Does that help?
comments.author: Illusion Blade

comments.text:
+Illusion Blade Haha as a French this is getting really confusing reading 
you guys !
comments.author: Dave Sheik

comments.text:
Hey there! Let me clear things up a bit.
Most importantly, different instruments have different do's. For example: 
Trumpet Do=C, Trombone Do=B flat, and so on. What you speak of (do re 
mi...) is named solfege. Consider them like algebraic letters. They can 
represent whatever you like, just as long as it is for your instrument. The 
letters (a b c d...) are the actual notes, or pitches. They are the actual 
musical notes. 
So in summary, A, B, C, and so on are the actual pitches, and Do, Re, Mi, 
and so on represent the letters. Hope I could help!
comments.author: Illusion Blade

comments.text:
+Oswyn Wincheriarty No podria ser mas de acuerdo, uso a los dos tambien.

comments.text:
+Rabbid Zombie +Dave Sheik I'm from Spain and I use the Do Re Mi notation 
since I was a child. But in my cello classes I use different books: In one 
of them (a method by S. Lee), I use Do Re Mi notation and in the other one 
(Suzuki Method, that is in English), I use the ABC one. I prefer the first 
one, beacause I'm used to it and for me is more beautiful. I think that 
know both systems is helpeful, but none of them is superior. They are just 
different. ^^

top_comment.author: gemcutter187

comments.text:
The name of the note is in regards to how many are in a measure, or time 
farm when getting into triplets and quintuplets and such. But eight notes 
can be in a measure in 4/4 eight times, or take up an eighth of the 
measure, quarter notes take up half in 4/4 or Common, half takes half, 
whole takes up the whole thing in common time, sixteenth notes take up 
sixteenths, etc. it starts to get more complicated when you get into non 
2^x type values, like how triplets can be 3 notes in an eighth note, 
quarter note, half note, or whole note depending on how they are notated, 
really any basic note that is a 2^x styles of note vakue. But that is 
getting into more intermediate not very beginner notation.
comments.author: gameguy8101

comments.text:
4/4 time is the most common time. Another name for it is common time, and 
sometimes instead of a "4/4" you'll see a large "C" where a time signature 
normally sits. Most music you hear is in common time, so it is what the 
math behind music is based on. A whole note fills an entire measure in 4/4 
time, a half note fills half a measure in 4/4 time, a quarter note fills a 
quarter measure in 4/4 time, and an eighth note fills an eighth of a 
measure in 4/4 time. Therefore, since a whole measure in 4/4 is four beats, 
a whole note is four beats, half is two beats, quarter is one beat, eighth 
is half a beat.

comments.text:
+William Hsu It’s actually not all that weird if you take a look at the 
spread of their note range. The viola, for instance, has a note-range just 
below that of a violin (which normally uses the treble clef), so using 
either the treble or the bass clef would result in either too many ledger 
lines or more persistent clef-swapping between the treble clef and the bass 
clef.

top_comment.text:
This is very well done. I was going to vote for it but the section in 4:23 
and beyond where the pitches of the rhythms are played of "Joyful, Joyful" 
with the wrong pitches drove me a bit crazy. Very confusing for new 
musicians to hear notes that should go up and then notated as down the 
staff instead. Please fix this and it would be awesome.﻿
top_comment.author: Luanne Fose

comments.author: Matthew Pablo

captions.text: When we watch a film or a play,
we know that the actors

probably learned
their lines from a script,

which essentially tells them
what to say and when to say it.

A piece of written music
operates on exactly the same principle.
In a very basic sense,

it tells a performer what to play
and when to play it.

Aesthetically speaking,
there's a world of difference
between, say, Beethoven and Justin Bieber,
but both artists have used

the same building blocks
to create their music:
notes.

And although the end result
can sound quite complicated,

the logic behind musical notes
is actually pretty straightforward.
Let's take a look

at the foundational
elements to music notation

and how they interact
to create a work of art.

Music is written on five parallel lines
that go across the page.
These five lines are called a staff,
and a staff operates on two axes:
up and down
and left to right.
The up-and-down axis tells the performer

the pitch of the note
or what note to play,
and the left-to-right axis
tells the performer the rhythm of the note
or when to play it.
Let's start with pitch.

To help us out,
we're going to use a piano,

but this system works for pretty much
any instrument you can think of.
In the Western music tradition,

pitches are named after
the first seven letters of the alphabet,
A, B, C,
D, E, F, and G.
After that, the cycle repeats itself:
A, B, C, D, E, F, G,
A, B, C, D, E, F, G,
and so on.
But how do these pitches get their names?
Well, for example, if you played an F
and then played another F
higher or lower on the piano,

you'd notice that they sound
pretty similar
compared to, say, a B.
Going back to the staff,

every line and every space
between two lines
represents a separate pitch.

If we put a note on one of these lines
or one of these spaces,

we're telling a performer
to play that pitch.

The higher up on the staff
a note is placed,
the higher the pitch.

But there are obviously
many, many more pitches

than the nine that these
lines and spaces gives us.
A grand piano, for example,
can play 88 separate notes.

So how do we condense
88 notes onto a single staff?
We use something called a clef,

a weird-looking figure
placed at the beginning of the staff,
which acts like a reference point,

telling you that a particular
line or space

corresponds to a specific note
on your instrument.

If we want to play notes
that aren't on the staff,

we kind of cheat and draw
extra little lines
called ledger lines
and place the notes on them.

If we have to draw so many ledger lines
that it gets confusing,

then we need to change
to a different clef.

As for telling a performer
when to play the notes,
two main elements control this:
the beat and the rhythm.
The beat of a piece of music is,
by itself, kind of boring.
It sounds like this.
(Ticking)
Notice that it doesn't change,
it just plugs along quite happily.
It can go slow
or fast
or whatever you like, really.

The point is that just
like the second hand on a clock
divides one minute into sixty seconds,

with each second just as long
as every other second,
the beat divides a piece of music

into little fragments of time
that are all the same length:
beats.
With a steady beat as a foundation,
we can add rhythm to our pitches,

and that's when music
really starts to happen.
This is a quarter note.
It's the most basic unit of rhythm,
and it's worth one beat.

This is a half note,
and it's worth two beats.
This whole note here is worth four beats,
and these little guys are eighth notes,
worth half a beat each.
"Great," you say, "what does that mean?"

You might have noticed
that across the length of a staff,

there are little lines dividing it
into small sections.
These are bar lines
and we refer to each section as a bar.
At the beginning of a piece of music,
just after the clef,
is something called the time signature,

which tells a performer
how many beats are in each bar.
This says there are two beats in each bar,
this says there are three,
this one four, and so on.

The bottom number tells
us what kind of note

is to be used as the basic
unit for the beat.
One corresponds to a whole note,
two to a half note,
four to a quarter note,
and eight to an eighth note, and so on.
So this time signature here

tells us that there are four
quarter notes in each bar,
one, two, three, four;
one, two, three, four,
and so on.
But like I said before,
if we just stick to the beat,
it gets kind of boring,

so we'll replace some quarter notes
with different rhythms.

Notice that even though
the number of notes
in each bar has changed,

the total number of beats
in each bar hasn't.

So, what does our musical
creation sound like?
(Music)

Eh, sounds okay, but maybe
a bit thin, right?

Let's add another instrument
with its own pitch and rhythm.
Now it's sounding like music.

Sure, it takes some practice
to get used to reading it quickly
and playing what we see on our instrument,
but, with a bit of time and patience,
you could be the next Beethoven
or Justin Bieber.

title: How to read music - Tim Hansen
